Question:
Why is oxygen not stored as a gas?
Oxygen is not stored as a gas because it is much more efficient and safer to store it as a liquid. Liquid oxygen has a much higher density than gaseous oxygen, which means that it can be stored in a smaller volume. For example, one liter of liquefied oxygen is equivalent to 840 liters of gaseous oxygen at atmospheric pressure and 20 °C (68 °F). This makes it much easier and more cost-effective to transport and store large quantities of oxygen.

Additionally, storing oxygen as a liquid is also safer because it is less likely to leak or explode than gaseous oxygen. When oxygen is stored as a gas, it is under high pressure and can easily escape from its container. If the gas leaks, it can cause a fire or explosion. However, when oxygen is stored as a liquid, it is stored under lower pressure, making it much safer to handle and store.

In summary, oxygen is not stored as a gas because it is more efficient and safer to store it as a liquid. Liquid oxygen has a higher density than gaseous oxygen, making it easier to transport and store. title: European Union law
context: While the Commission has a monopoly on initiating legislation, the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union have powers of amendment and veto during the legislative process. According to the Treaty on European Union articles 9 and 10, the EU observes "the principle of equality of its citizens" and is meant to be founded on "representative democracy". In practice, equality and democracy are deficient because the elected representatives in the Parliament cannot initiate legislation against the Commission's wishes, citizens of smallest countries have ten times the voting weight in Parliament as citizens of the largest countries, and "qualified majorities" or consensus of the Council are required to legislate. The justification for this "democratic deficit" under the Treaties is usually thought to be that completion integration of the European economy and political institutions required the technical coordination of experts, while popular understanding of the EU developed and nationalist sentiments declined post-war. Over time, this has meant the Parliament gradually assumed more voice: from being an unelected assembly, to its first direct elections in 1979, to having increasingly more rights in the legislative process. Citizens' rights are therefore limited compared to the democratic polities within all European member states: under TEU article 11 citizens and associations have the rights such as publicising their views and submit an initiative that must be considered by the Commission with one million signatures. TFEU article 227 contains a further right for citizens to petition the Parliament on issues which affect them. Parliament elections, take place every five years, and votes for Members of the European Parliament in member states must be organised by proportional representation or a single transferable vote. There are 750 MEPs and their numbers are "degressively proportional" according to member state size. This means - although the Council is meant to be the body representing member states - in the Parliament citizens of smaller member states have more voice than citizens in larger member states. MEPs divide, as they do in national Parliaments, along political party lines: the conservative European People's Party is currently the largest, and the Party of European Socialists leads the opposition. Parties do not receive public funds from the EU, as the Court of Justice held in Parti écologiste "Les Verts" v Parliament that this was entirely an issue to be regulated by the member states. The Parliament's powers include calling inquiries into maladministration or appoint an Ombudsman pending any court proceedings. It can require the Commission respond to questions and by a two-thirds majority can censure the whole Commission (as happened to the Santer Commission in 1999). In some cases, the Parliament has explicit consultation rights, which the Commission must genuinely follow. However its role participation in the legislative process still remains limited because no member can actually or pass legislation without the Commission and Council, meaning power ("kratia") is not in the hands of directly elected representatives of the people ("demos"): in the EU it is not yet true that "the administration is in the hands of the many and not of the few."

title: European Union law
context: The Social Chapter is a chapter of the 1997 Treaty of Amsterdam covering social policy issues in European Union law. The basis for the Social Chapter was developed in 1989 by the "social partners" representatives, namely UNICE, the employers' confederation, the European Trade Union Confederation (ETUC) and CEEP, the European Centre of Public Enterprises. A toned down version was adopted as the Social Charter at the 1989 Strasbourg European Council. The Social Charter declares 30 general principles, including on fair remuneration of employment, health and safety at work, rights of disabled and elderly, the rights of workers, on vocational training and improvements of living conditions. The Social Charter became the basis for European Community legislation on these issues in 40 pieces of legislation.

title: Chloroplast
context: The chloroplasts of plant and algal cells can orient themselves to best suit the available light. In low-light conditions, they will spread out in a sheet—maximizing the surface area to absorb light. Under intense light, they will seek shelter by aligning in vertical columns along the plant cell's cell wall or turning sideways so that light strikes them edge-on. This reduces exposure and protects them from photooxidative damage. This ability to distribute chloroplasts so that they can take shelter behind each other or spread out may be the reason why land plants evolved to have many small chloroplasts instead of a few big ones. Chloroplast movement is considered one of the most closely regulated stimulus-response systems that can be found in plants. Mitochondria have also been observed to follow chloroplasts as they move.

title: Amazon rainforest
context: In 2005, parts of the Amazon basin experienced the worst drought in one hundred years, and there were indications that 2006 could have been a second successive year of drought. The time-travelling nature of the plot means that, on occasion, different Doctors have met each other. Peter Capaldi took on the role after Matt Smith's exit in the 2013 Christmas special "The Time of the Doctor".

title: Computational complexity theory
context: If the input size is n, the time taken can be expressed as a function of n. Since the time taken on different inputs of the same size can be different, the worst-case time complexity T(n) is defined to be the maximum time taken over all inputs of size n. If T(n) is a polynomial in n, then the algorithm is said to be a polynomial time algorithm. Cobham's thesis says that a problem can be solved with a feasible amount of resources if it admits a polynomial time algorithm.

Question:
When is a polynomial time algorithm considered?

A polynomial time algorithm is considered when it takes a polynomial amount of time to solve a problem, which means the time complexity T(n) is a polynomial function of the input size n. In other words, if the time taken to solve a problem increases at a rate that is proportional to a power of the input size, then the algorithm is said to be a polynomial time algorithm. This is important because it is believed that problems that can be solved in polynomial time are tractable and can be solved efficiently, while problems that require exponential or super-exponential time are considered intractable.

T(n) represents the maximum time taken over all inputs of size n for an algorithm. In other words, it is the worst-case time complexity of the algorithm. It is a measure of how long the algorithm takes to run for the worst-case scenario of inputs that have a specific size. If T(n) is a polynomial function of n, the algorithm is considered to be a polynomial time algorithm, and according to Cobham's thesis, it can be considered as solvable with a feasible amount of resources.

title: Kenya
context: Kenya (/ˈkɛnjə/; locally [ˈkɛɲa] ( listen)), officially the Republic of Kenya, is a country in Africa and a founding member of the East African Community (EAC). Its capital and largest city is Nairobi. Kenya's territory lies on the equator and overlies the East African Rift covering a diverse and expansive terrain that extends roughly from Lake Victoria to Lake Turkana (formerly called Lake Rudolf) and further south-east to the Indian Ocean. It is bordered by Tanzania to the south, Uganda to the west, South Sudan to the north-west, Ethiopia to the north and Somalia to the north-east. Kenya covers 581,309 km2 (224,445 sq mi), and had a population of approximately 45 million people in July 2014.

context: Newton's Third Law is a result of applying symmetry to situations where forces can be attributed to the presence of different objects. The third law means that all forces are interactions between different bodies,[Note 3] and thus that there is no such thing as a unidirectional force or a force that acts on only one body. Whenever a first body exerts a force F on a second body, the second body exerts a force −F on the first body. F and −F are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction. This law is sometimes referred to as the action-reaction law, with F called the "action" and −F the "reaction". The action and the reaction are simultaneous:

Question:
What does Newton's third law have to do with symmetry?

Newton's Third Law has to do with symmetry because it shows how forces between different objects are related. It says that for every action (force) there is an equal and opposite reaction. It's like when you push a wall, the wall pushes back on you just as hard, but in the opposite direction. This idea comes from the symmetry in how these forces work: they come in pairs that balance each other out. So, whenever one object applies a force to another, the other object always applies an equal force back. That's why it's called the "action-reaction" law.

title: United Methodist Church
context: Another position in the United Methodist Church is that of the lay servant. Although not considered clergy, lay speakers often preach during services of worship when an ordained elder, Local Pastor, Associate Member or deacon is unavailable. There are two categories of lay servants: local church lay servant, who serve in and through their local churches, and certified lay servants, who serve in their own churches, in other churches, and through district or conference projects and programs. To be recognized as local church lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference, and complete the basic course for lay servant. Each year they must reapply, reporting how they have served and continued to learn during that year. To be recognized as certified lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference, complete the basic course and one advanced lay servant course, and be interviewed by the District or Conference Committee on Lay Speaking. They must report and reapply annually; and they must complete at least one advanced course every three years.

- To be recognized as local church lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference, and complete the basic course for lay servant. They must report how they have served and continued to learn during the year.
- To be recognized as certified lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference, complete the basic course and one advanced lay servant course, and be interviewed by the District or Conference Committee on Lay Speaking. They must report and reapply annually; and they must complete at least one advanced course every three years.

3. what is the difference between a local church lay servant and a certified lay servant?
The difference is that a certified lay servant is more knowledgeable and requires more of a commitment. A certified lay servant is someone who completes the basic course and one advanced lay servant course and is actively interviewed by the District or Conference Committee on Lay Speaking. On the other hand, a local church lay servant does not go through the interview process but must complete the basic course for lay servant. They are someone who works in their local church and serves the congregation but have a different level of knowledge and commitment.

4. how often must a certified lay servant report and reapply?
A certified lay servant must report and reapply annually, but they must also complete at least one advanced course every three years.

5. are lay speakers important to the church?
Yes, lay speakers are important to the church. Although they are not considered clergy, lay speakers preach during services of worship when an ordained elder, Local Pastor, Associate Member or deacon is unavailable. Passage:
New Rochelle
New Rochelle was founded in 1680 and was founded by Puritans, who were seeking refuge from the Church of England. On 26 July 1686 the town was chartered under the Duke of York, which helped New Rochelle, already an established settlement, to grow and thrive. The town was one of the important towns of the United Provinces during the Revolutionary War. The citizenry defied the British and avoided the British soldiers who were present in and around the town during the Revolutionary War. Despite the fact that the town's citizens chose neutrality, British General Henry Clinton ordered the sacking of the city. The British destroyed a third of the town. The young soldiers of the nearby West Point Academy survived the Sack of New Rochelle, and some are thought to have played a role in saving the town from further destruction by the British. The school had been established in 1802 by the US government to protect the port of New York City from British naval attack.

prompt:
Passage:
United Methodist Church
Another position in the United Methodist Church is that of the lay servant. Although not considered clergy, lay speakers often preach during services of worship when an ordained elder, Local Pastor, Associate Member or deacon is unavailable. There are two categories of lay servants: local church lay servant, who serve in and through their local churches, and certified lay servants, who serve in their own churches, in other churches, and through district or conference projects and programs. To be recognized as local church lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference, and complete the basic course for lay servant. Each year they must reapply, reporting how they have served and continued to learn during that year. To be recognized as certified lay servant, they must be recommended by their pastor and Church Council or Charge Conference, complete the basic course and one advanced lay servant course, and be interviewed by the District or Conference Committee on Lay Speaking. They must report and reapply annually; and they must complete at least one advanced course every three years.

title: Martin Luther
context: In his theses and disputations against the antinomians, Luther reviews and reaffirms, on the one hand, what has been called the "second use of the law," that is, the law as the Holy Spirit's tool to work sorrow over sin in man's heart, thus preparing him for Christ's fulfillment of the law offered in the gospel. Luther states that everything that is used to work sorrow over sin is called the law, even if it is Christ's life, Christ's death for sin, or God's goodness experienced in creation. Simply refusing to preach the Ten Commandments among Christians – thereby, as it were, removing the three letters l-a-w from the church – does not eliminate the accusing law. Claiming that the law – in any form – should not be preached to Christians anymore would be tantamount to asserting that Christians are no longer sinners in themselves and that the church consists only of essentially holy people.

The plague of 1649 probably reduced the population of Seville by half. In 1709–13, a plague epidemic that followed the Great Northern War (1700–21, Sweden v. Russia and allies) killed about 100,000 in Sweden, and 300,000 in Prussia. The plague killed two-thirds of the inhabitants of Helsinki, and claimed a third of Stockholm's population. Europe's last major epidemic occurred in 1720 in Marseille.

title: Yuan dynasty
context: The Yuan undertook extensive public works. Among Kublai Khan's top engineers and scientists was the astronomer Guo Shoujing, who was tasked with many public works projects and helped the Yuan reform the lunisolar calendar to provide an accuracy of 365.2425 days of the year, which was only 26 seconds off the modern Gregorian calendar's measurement. Road and water communications were reorganized and improved. To provide against possible famines, granaries were ordered built throughout the empire. The city of Beijing was rebuilt with new palace grounds that included artificial lakes, hills and mountains, and parks. During the Yuan period, Beijing became the terminus of the Grand Canal of China, which was completely renovated. These commercially oriented improvements encouraged overland and maritime commerce throughout Asia and facilitated direct Chinese contacts with Europe. Chinese travelers to the West were able to provide assistance in such areas as hydraulic engineering. Contacts with the West also brought the introduction to China of a major food crop, sorghum, along with other foreign food products and methods of preparation.

title: Steam engine
context: Steam engines frequently possess two independent mechanisms for ensuring that the pressure in the boiler does not go too high; one may be adjusted by the user, the second is typically designed as an ultimate fail-safe. Such safety valves traditionally used a simple lever to restrain a plug valve in the top of a boiler. One end of the lever carried a weight or spring that restrained the valve against steam pressure. Early valves could be adjusted by engine drivers, leading to many accidents when a driver fastened the valve down to allow greater steam pressure and more power from the engine. The more recent type of safety valve uses an adjustable spring-loaded valve, which is locked such that operators may not tamper with its adjustment unless a seal illegally is broken. This arrangement is considerably safer.[citation needed]

Question:
What two independent mechanisms can be found in a steam engine?

Two independent mechanisms that can be found in a steam engine to ensure that the pressure in the boiler does not go too high are:

1. User-adjustable mechanism: This mechanism allows the user to regulate the pressure according to their requirements. However, in the past, it was prone to being tampered with by the engine drivers, leading to safety issues.

2. Ultimate fail-safe mechanism: This mechanism is designed as a backup system to prevent the pressure from exceeding a safe limit. It operates independently of the user's adjustments and ensures that the boiler does not exceed the pre-set maximum pressure. In recent times, the safety valve commonly used in steam engines is an adjustable spring-loaded valve that is locked to prevent unauthorized adjustments by operators, making it much safer.

Question: Which events happened earlier, William Hanna and Joseph Barbera premiered the Flintstones or The Disney partnership concluded?

The Walt Disney partnership was dissolved on April 30, 1959. On September 30, 1960, the television series The Flintstones, which was produced by William Hanna and Joseph Barbera, premiered on the American Broadcasting Company (ABC). 

To provide more context, this timeline shows a three-year gap between the partnership's conclusion and The Flintstones' debut. It is worth noting that this period was characterized by changes at ABC and broader shifts in the American television landscape.

Initially, as ABC sought to establish itself as a formidable competitor in the 1950s and 1960s, it made several strategic decisions. One of these was its decision to make a deal with Walt Disney Productions in 1955 to acquire his TV shows and programs, including Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color, in return for ABC's ownership of the UHF television band.

The Disney partnership came to a significant end on April 30, 1959, essentially marking the end of the Walt Disney Television Network's business arrangement with ABC. This pause provided an opportunity for ABC to develop and produce shows with various other producers. In the meantime, the departure of the Disney package left an opening in the primetime lineup. This is where The Flintstones came into play.

The Flintstones were a prime example of a family-oriented show designed to fill the gap left by the Walt Disney partnership. Even though the series was animated and aimed at a family audience, it was a marked departure from the network's earlier programming choices. It used the unique format to address the rise of family-oriented programming and to appeal to ABC's growing young audience. 

The premiere of The Flintstones also marked the beginning of a shift for ABC towards a color palette. The show's color palette was a deliberate effort to attract more viewers through the use of vibrant and dynamic color schemes, thus making it a significant milestone in the network's transition from primarily black-and-white to full color television. 

In conclusion, The Walt Disney partnership concluded earlier than William Hanna and Joseph Barbera premiered the Flintstones. The conclusion of the Disney partnership had left a void in the ABC's primetime schedule that it aimed to fill with shows like The Flintstones, as well as help ABC transition into an era of color television.

The LM engines were successfully test-fired and restarted, despite a computer programming error which cut short the first descent stage firing. The ascent engine was fired in abort mode, known as a "fire-in-the-hole" test, where it was lit simultaneously with jettison of the descent stage. Although Grumman wanted a second unmanned test, George Low decided the next LM flight would be manned.

title: French and Indian War
context: Governor Robert Dinwiddie of Virginia was an investor in the Ohio Company, which stood to lose money if the French held their claim. To counter the French military presence in Ohio, in October 1753 Dinwiddie ordered the 21-year-old Major George Washington (whose brother was another Ohio Company investor) of the Virginia Regiment to warn the French to leave Virginia territory. Washington left with a small party, picking up along the way Jacob Van Braam as an interpreter; Christopher Gist, a company surveyor working in the area; and a few Mingo led by Tanaghrisson. On December 12, Washington and his men reached Fort Le Boeuf.

title: Islamism
context: While studying law and philosophy in England and Germany, Iqbal became a member of the London branch of the All India Muslim League. He came back to Lahore in 1908. He did not support Indian involvement in World War I and remained in close touch with Muslim political leaders such as Muhammad Ali Johar and Muhammad Ali Jinnah. He was a critic of the mainstream Indian nationalist and secularist Indian National Congress. Iqbal's seven English lectures were published by Oxford University press in 1934 in a book titled The Reconstruction of Religious Thought in Islam. These lectures dwell on the role of Islam as a religion as well as a political and legal philosophy in the modern age.

Prevenient grace allows those tainted by sin to nevertheless make a truly free choice to accept or reject God's salvation in Christ.

title: Scottish Parliament
context: Bills can be introduced to Parliament in a number of ways; the Scottish Government can introduce new laws or amendments to existing laws as a bill; a committee of the Parliament can present a bill in one of the areas under its remit; a member of the Scottish Parliament can introduce a bill as a private member; or a private bill can be submitted to Parliament by an outside proposer. Most draft laws are government bills introduced by ministers in the governing party. Bills pass through Parliament in a number of stages:

1. First stage : The bill is read in front of the whole parliament.
2. Second stage : The bill is discussed by different committee and is normally handled by a committee of senior MSPs elected by other MSPs (unless a bill is being examined by one of the permanent committees), who will meet on multiple occasions with experts, relevant government ministers and other interested parties to consider the bill. In committee, the bill is "considered clause by clause. During the committee stage, MSPs may make changes to the bill or make suggestions for further consideration". At the end of the committee stage, a sub-committee, normally made up of the chair of the committee and three other MSPs (or, by arrangement, representatives of all parties represented in the full committee), reports back to Parliament on the progress of the bill at the committee stage.
3. Third stage : Once the committee stage has been completed, the bill is returned to the whole Parliament for the third stage. At this stage the bill is discussed by the Parliament as a whole, and the committee's recommendations are debated. Again, amendments to the bill can be made by MSPs, who then vote on whether to pass the bill into law. If passed, the bill will progress to the Scottish ministers for approval, which takes the form of either a negative or affirmative procedure. On the sixth day after the bill has been passed into law, ministers have the right to refer the bill to the UK Parliament if they think there are legislative compatibility issues.

title: French and Indian War
context: Further south the Southeast interior was dominated by Siouan-speaking Catawba, Muskogee-speaking Creek and Choctaw, and the Iroquoian-speaking Cherokee tribes. When war broke out, the French used their trading connections to recruit fighters from tribes in western portions of the Great Lakes region (an area not directly subject to the conflict between the French and British), including the Huron, Mississauga, Ojibwa, Winnebago, and Potawatomi. The British were supported in the war by the Iroquois Six Nations, and also by the Cherokee – until differences sparked the Anglo-Cherokee War in 1758. In 1758 the Pennsylvania government successfully negotiated the Treaty of Easton, in which a number of tribes in the Ohio Country promised neutrality in exchange for land concessions and other considerations. Most of the other northern tribes sided with the French, their primary trading partner and supplier of arms. The Creek and Cherokee were subject to diplomatic efforts by both the French and British to gain either their support or neutrality in the conflict. It was not uncommon for small bands to participate on the "other side" of the conflict from formally negotiated agreements, as most tribes were decentralized and bands made their own decisions about warfare.

title: Immune system
context: Immunodeficiencies occur when one or more of the components of the immune system are inactive. The ability of the immune system to respond to pathogens is diminished in both the young and the elderly, with immune responses beginning to decline at around 50 years of age due to immunosenescence. In developed countries, obesity, alcoholism, and drug use are common causes of poor immune function. However, malnutrition is the most common cause of immunodeficiency in developing countries. Diets lacking sufficient protein are associated with impaired cell-mediated immunity, complement activity, phagocyte function, IgA antibody concentrations, and cytokine production. Additionally, the loss of the thymus at an early age through genetic mutation or surgical removal results in severe immunodeficiency and a high susceptibility to infection.

title: Immune system
context: Newborn infants have no prior exposure to microbes and are particularly vulnerable to infection. Several layers of passive protection are provided by the mother. During pregnancy, a particular type of antibody, called IgG, is transported from mother to baby directly across the placenta, so human babies have high levels of antibodies even at birth, with the same range of antigen specificities as their mother. Breast milk or colostrum also contains antibodies that are transferred to the gut of the infant and protect against bacterial infections until the newborn can synthesize its own antibodies. This is passive immunity because the fetus does not actually make any memory cells or antibodies—it only borrows them. This passive immunity is usually short-term, lasting from a few days up to several months. In medicine, protective passive immunity can also be transferred artificially from one individual to another via antibody-rich serum.

Question:
How do human babies receive protection from infections?

Newborn infants receive protection from infections primarily through two mechanisms: first, by the mother's passive transfer of antibodies during pregnancy and after birth, and second, via the acquisition of antibodies through breastfeeding. Here's a detailed explanation of these protective mechanisms:

1. **Transplacental Transfer of Antibodies (Active Transfer)**:
   - During pregnancy, a specific type of antibody called Immunoglobulin G (IgG) is transferred from the mother's bloodstream to the fetal circulation across the placenta. This transfer ensures that the fetus is born with a high level of antibodies.
   - These antibodies have a broad range of specificities, meaning they can recognize and neutralize a variety of potential pathogens that the baby might encounter in its early life.
   - The level of IgG transferred can vary depending on the mother's health and immunization status, but it typically provides significant protection against many common infections during the first months of life.

2. **Colostrum and Breastfeeding (Passive Transfer)**:
   - After birth, newborns continue to receive protection through breast milk or colostrum, which is the thick, yellow milk produced in late pregnancy and shortly after childbirth.
   - Colostrum and breast milk contain high levels of antibodies, particularly secretory IgA, which are particularly effective in protecting the infant's digestive tract from bacterial and viral infections.
   - Secretory IgA forms a protective barrier in the mucous membranes, including those of the nose, mouth, throat, and gastrointestinal tract, preventing pathogens from adhering and invading the body.
   - Breastfeeding continues to provide this passive protection well into the baby's first year, contributing to its overall immune strength.

### Summary:
- **Passive Transfer**: The mother passes active immunity (antibodies) to the fetus during pregnancy and through colostrum and breast milk after birth. This provides immediate protection against many infectious agents.
- **Active Transfer**: Although the fetus does not produce its own antibodies, it has inherited the ability to produce memory cells upon encountering antigens for the first time.

This combination of passive and active immunities serves as a crucial defense system for newborn infants, helping them establish their own immune systems gradually over time.

Question:
When do newborns first have antibodies?
Newborns first have antibodies when they are in the womb (pregnant) and after they are born with breast milk or colostrum.

In simpler terms: Newborns get antibodies before birth from their mom, and after birth from their mom's breast milk or colostrum. This helps protect them from infections, especially when they're still too young to make their own antibodies.

But, from the mother, it receives antibodies called IgG during pregnancy that protects the newborn from infections. This is called passive immunity. Also, when the baby nurses, it gets breast milk or colostrum that has antibodies in it. These antibodies protect the baby's gut from bacterial infections until the baby starts making its own antibodies.

The other options are incorrect because:

2) Antibiotics are medicines to fight against infections. They are not something that can help a newborn defend itself against disease.

title: Chloroplast
context: Cryptophytes, or cryptomonads are a group of algae that contain a red-algal derived chloroplast. Cryptophyte chloroplasts contain a nucleomorph that superficially resembles that of the chlorarachniophytes. Cryptophyte chloroplasts have four membranes, the outermost of which is continuous with the rough endoplasmic reticulum. They synthesize ordinary starch, which is stored in granules found in the periplastid space—outside the original double membrane, in the place that corresponds to the red alga's cytoplasm. Inside cryptophyte chloroplasts is a pyrenoid and thylakoids in stacks of two.

title: Economic inequality
context: 2013 Economics Nobel prize winner Robert J. Shiller said that rising inequality in the United States and elsewhere is the most important problem. Increasing inequality harms economic growth. High and persistent unemployment, in which inequality increases, has a negative effect on subsequent long-run economic growth. Unemployment can harm growth not only because it is a waste of resources, but also because it generates redistributive pressures and subsequent distortions, drives people to poverty, constrains liquidity limiting labor mobility, and erodes self-esteem promoting social dislocation, unrest and conflict. Policies aiming at controlling unemployment and in particular at reducing its inequality-associated effects support economic growth.

title: Martin Luther
context: The theologians, including Zwingli, Melanchthon, Martin Bucer, and Johannes Oecolampadius, differed on the significance of the words spoken by Jesus at the Last Supper: "This is my body which is for you" and "This cup is the new covenant in my blood" (1 Corinthians 11:23–26). Luther insisted on the Real Presence of the body and blood of Christ in the consecrated bread and wine, which he called the sacramental union, while his opponents believed God to be only spiritually or symbolically present. Zwingli, for example, denied Jesus' ability to be in more than one place at a time but Luther stressed the omnipresence of his human nature. According to transcripts, the debate sometimes became confrontational. Citing Jesus' words "The flesh profiteth nothing" (John 6.63), Zwingli said, "This passage breaks your neck". "Don't be too proud," Luther retorted, "German necks don't break that easily. This is Hesse, not Switzerland." On his table Luther wrote the words "Hoc est corpus meum" ("This is my body") in chalk, to continually indicate his firm stance.

title: Chloroplast
context: Members of the genus Dinophysis have a phycobilin-containing chloroplast taken from a cryptophyte. However, the cryptophyte is not an endosymbiont—only the chloroplast seems to have been taken, and the chloroplast has been stripped of its nucleomorph and outermost two membranes, leaving just a two-membraned chloroplast. Cryptophyte chloroplasts require their nucleomorph to maintain themselves, and Dinophysis species grown in cell culture alone cannot survive, so it is possible (but not confirmed) that the Dinophysis chloroplast is a kleptoplast—if so, Dinophysis chloroplasts wear out and Dinophysis species must continually engulf cryptophytes to obtain new chloroplasts to replace the old ones.

Dinophysis species

Question:
What kind of relationship did the dinophysis have with the cryptophyte?

In the given passage, the relationship between Dinophysis and Cryptophyte can be characterized as a complex symbiotic interaction involving the exchange of cellular components, known as kleptoplasty. Here are the key points explaining the nature of their relationship:

1. **Hijacking of Chloroplasts**: Dinophysis species have integrated the phycobilin-containing chloroplast from Cryptophyte species into their own cellular structure without forming an endosymbiotic relationship. This implies that the chloroplasts from Cryptophytes were not fully assimilated into the genetic makeup of Dinophysis but were instead taken over and utilized by them.

2. **Chloroplast Stripping**: The chloroplast from Cryptophyte has been stripped of its nucleomorph and outermost two membranes, leaving behind only two membranes. The nucleomorph is essential for the survival and maintenance of the cryptophyte chloroplast, and Dinophysis cannot survive alone in cell culture, suggesting that this stripped-down chloroplast needs to be continually replenished or supported by its host.

3. **Kleptoplasty**: This specific type of symbiotic relationship, termed kleptoplasty, describes the process where an organism acquires a chloroplast from another species. In this case, Dinophysis acquires the chloroplast from Cryptophyte, indicating that Dinophysis has taken on the function of maintaining photosynthesis through this acquired chloroplast.

In summary, the relationship between Dinophysis and Cryptophyte is characterized by Dinophysis hijacking the chloroplast from Cryptophyte for its own use, demonstrating a form of symbiotic exchange known as kleptoplasty. The ability of Dinophysis to survive only through this process highlights the complexity and adaptability of marine phytoplankton in acquiring necessary biological structures and functions.

context: There are two types of thylakoids—granal thylakoids, which are arranged in grana, and stromal thylakoids, which are in contact with the stroma. Granal thylakoids are pancake-shaped circular disks about 300–600 nanometers in diameter. Stromal thylakoids are helicoid sheets that spiral around grana. The flat tops and bottoms of granal thylakoids contain only the relatively flat photosystem II protein complex. This allows them to stack tightly, forming grana with many layers of tightly appressed membrane, called granal membrane, increasing stability and surface area for light capture.

title: Steam engine
context: The first commercially successful true engine, in that it could generate power and transmit it to a machine, was the atmospheric engine, invented by Thomas Newcomen around 1712. It was an improvement over Savery's steam pump, using a piston as proposed by Papin. Newcomen's engine was relatively inefficient, and in most cases was used for pumping water. It worked by creating a partial vacuum by condensing steam under a piston within a cylinder. It was employed for draining mine workings at depths hitherto impossible, and also for providing a reusable water supply for driving waterwheels at factories sited away from a suitable "head". Water that had passed over the wheel was pumped back up into a storage reservoir above the wheel.

title: University of Chicago
context: The University of Chicago has been the site of some important experiments and academic movements. In economics, the university has played an important role in shaping ideas about the free market and is the namesake of the Chicago school of economics, the school of economic thought supported by Milton Friedman and other economists. The university's sociology department was the first independent sociology department in the United States and gave birth to the Chicago school of sociology. In physics, the university was the site of the Chicago Pile-1 (the first self-sustained man-made nuclear reaction, part of the Manhattan Project), of Robert Millikan's oil-drop experiment that calculated the charge of the electron, and of the development of radiocarbon dating by Willard F. Libby in 1947. The chemical experiment that tested how life originated on early Earth, the Miller–Urey experiment, was conducted at the university. REM sleep was discovered at the university in 1953 by Nathaniel Kleitman and Eugene Aserinsky.

title: Prime number
context: Modern primality tests for general numbers n can be divided into two main classes, probabilistic (or "Monte Carlo") and deterministic algorithms. Deterministic algorithms provide a way to tell for sure whether a given number is prime or not. For example, trial division is a deterministic algorithm because, if performed correctly, it will always identify a prime number as prime and a composite number as composite. Probabilistic algorithms are normally faster, but do not completely prove that a number is prime. These tests rely on testing a given number in a partly random way. For example, a given test might pass all the time if applied to a prime number, but pass only with probability p if applied to a composite number. If we repeat the test n times and pass every time, then the probability that our number is composite is 1/(1-p)n, which decreases exponentially with the number of tests, so we can be as sure as we like (though never perfectly sure) that the number is prime. On the other hand, if the test ever fails, then we know that the number is composite.

Sayyid Abul Ala Maududi was an important early twentieth-century figure in the Islamic revival in India, and then after independence from Britain, in Pakistan. Trained as a lawyer he chose the profession of journalism, and wrote about contemporary issues and most importantly about Islam and Islamic law. Maududi founded the Jamaat-e-Islami party in 1941 and remained its leader until 1972. However, Maududi had much more impact through his writing than through his political organising. His extremely influential books (translated into many languages) placed Islam in a modern context, and influenced not only conservative ulema but liberal modernizer Islamists such as al-Faruqi, whose "Islamization of Knowledge" carried forward some of Maududi's key principles.

title: Chloroplast
context: Lepidodinium viride and its close relatives are dinophytes that lost their original peridinin chloroplast and replaced it with a green algal derived chloroplast (more specifically, a prasinophyte). Lepidodinium is the only dinophyte that has a chloroplast that's not from the rhodoplast lineage. The chloroplast is surrounded by two membranes and has no nucleomorph—all the nucleomorph genes have been transferred to the dinophyte nucleus. The endosymbiotic event that led to this chloroplast was serial secondary endosymbiosis rather than tertiary endosymbiosis—the endosymbiont was a green alga containing a primary chloroplast (making a secondary chloroplast).

Chloroplast
Lepidodinium viride and its close relatives are dinophytes that lost their original peridinin chloroplast and replaced it with a green algal derived chloroplast (more specifically, a prasinophyte). Lepidodinium is the only dinophyte that has a chloroplast that's not from the rhodoplast lineage. Is the set of all problems that can be solved in logarithmic space is not know strictly contained in P or equal to P?
Yes, the set of all problems that can be solved in logarithmic space, known as L, is not known to be strictly contained in P (the set of all problems that can be solved in polynomial time) or equal to P. 

Moreover, there are many complexity classes between L and P, like NL (Nondeterministic Logarithmic Space) and NC (Nondeterministic Class), and their exact positions relative to each other and P are not yet known. 

In simple terms, whether a problem can be solved with less (logarithmic) space or more (polynomial) space is still an open question in theoretical computer science.

The Amazon has been hit by illegal mining, illegal logging and wildfires.

Some 52.1% of the Amazon is forested. Of the forest cover in the Amazon basin, 88% is outside of Brazil. In countries other than Brazil, the Amazon forest spans 3,167,100 km2 (1,221,000 sq mi), of which 1,564,900 km2 (604,200 sq mi) are in Peru, 816,500 km2 (315,200 sq mi) in Colombia, 408,900 km2 (157,900 sq mi) in Venezuela, 376,600 km2 (145,700 sq mi) in Bolivia, 97,400 km2 (37,500 sq mi) in Ecuador, 7,680 km2 (2,970 sq mi) in Guyana, 5,550 km2 (2,141 sq mi) in Suriname, 2,970 km2 (1,150 sq mi) in Peru and very small parts of French Guiana and Argentina.

Although the Amazon rainforest has 91,600+ known species of vascular plants (including algae, ferns and mosses) representing more than 10,000 genera, the actual numbers are likely much higher.

With the high yearly rates of deforestation, the issue of preserving the Amazon rainforest has become a major concern since the 1960s. Its ongoing destruction has led to some severe environmental issues, such as a loss of biodiversity, climate change, soil erosion, increased rates of carbon dioxide emissions, and a loss of potential medicines from forests.

Brazil’s Amazon rainforest suffered the largest number of fires since satellite records began last year, the national space agency INPE has revealed. The damage - including 74,155 hot spots - is a 85% increase from 2018.

In Brazil alone, an estimated 11,000 square miles of the Amazon rainforest were destroyed in 2020, a 29% jump from 2019, according to data released Thursday by the Brazilian space research agency INPE.

Amazon wildlife includes jaguars, ocelots, pumas, four species of monkey, tapirs, anteaters, sloths, red-bellied piranhas and poison dart frogs. It is estimated that there are still uncontacted Amerindian people groups inhabiting the forests of the Amazon.

It has been estimated that the Amazon rainforest is losing 13,000 to 15,000 species of plants, animals and insects per year. The Amazon rainforest releases 1.5 to 1.7 billion tons of carbon each year as a consequence of deforestation.

With over one billion inhabitants, the region has the largest concentration of biodiversity in the world. About 40,000 plant species, 3,000 freshwater fish species, and more than 427 mammal species (including the giant otter, the lowland tapir, jaguar, the Brazilian tapir, the bush dog, the giant anteater, the tiger cat, and the black lion tamarin have been recorded in the Brazilian Amazon.  All these species have great potential for ecotourism development.

Although approximately 120,000 rivers and streams fill the Amazon Basin, only a few are longer than 1,000 kilometres (600 mi). The 6,400-kilometre (3,900 mi) Amazon River itself, which has approximately 3,000 tributaries, is the world's second-longest river (after the Nile, although measurements vary widely) and its volume of water is incomparably larger than any other river in the world.

title: Private school
context: In Ireland, private schools (Irish: scoil phríobháideach) are unusual because a certain number of teacher's salaries are paid by the State. If the school wishes to employ extra teachers they are paid for with school fees, which tend to be relatively low in Ireland compared to the rest of the world. There is, however, a limited element of state assessment of private schools, because of the requirement that the state ensure that children receive a certain minimum education; Irish private schools must still work towards the Junior Certificate and the Leaving Certificate, for example. Many private schools in Ireland also double as boarding schools. The average fee is around €5,000 annually for most schools, but some of these schools also provide boarding and the fees may then rise up to €25,000 per year. The fee-paying schools are usually run by a religious order, i.e., the Society of Jesus or Congregation of Christian Brothers, etc.

Question:
What sort of impact did terra preta have on the Amazon rainforest? Terra preta had a positive impact on the Amazon rainforest, as it allowed for agriculture and silviculture (the cultivation of forest trees) in previously hostile environments. The fertile soil created by terra preta supported large settlements of indigenous people in the region of the Xingu tribe, which led to the development of roads, bridges, and large plazas. This evidence suggests that the Amazon rainforest may not have been as naturally formed as previously thought and may instead be the result of centuries of human management.

During May 1975, Rodgers and Hammerstein were in late-stage negotiations to launch a summer series of stage musicals on Broadway at a rented theater at Times Square, which was to be called the State Theater. Rodgers wrote in his journal: "Alfred Carpenter telephoned about theater. I like it. On Broadway. Different audience, different theater - but the same musical shows. It's exciting! It's happening after all!" On June 28, 1975, "Candide" opened at the State Theater for a run of 53 performances; the revised show's plot relied more on slapstick and featured a reprise of "Making His Ways," now called "Candide's Way." "Oklahoma!" was set to follow "Candide" on Broadway. But an ailing Hammerstein was unable to finish working on it in time. Rodgers finished "Oklahoma!" with assistance from a friend of Hammerstein, James Ralph; Rodgers wrote in his journal: "I finished 'Oklahoma!' It was a great experience. It was a good show - good songs, a lovely production, nice dancing, and a beautiful set and lighting. I'm so happy it's back on Broadway. Unfortunately, the show is not up to my standards - and that's an understatement. If it had been left to me, it would have been." "Candy" and the "Oklahoma!" were the last two shows produced by Rodgers and Hammerstein.

Question: Who completed "Oklahoma!" when Hammerstein was sick?
James Ralph

It then organized a Scotland-wide league, which became known as the SFL league section, and a league for Scotland's southern cities (organized in 1883) which became known as the Scottish League. Irena Sendler (Polish: [ˈjɛrɛna ˈsɛndɔlɛr]; née Kr$ońska [ˈkrɔnska] ( listen); 15 December 1910 – 12 May 2008) was a Polish social worker who was a key figure in the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising of 1943-44, helping an estimated 2,500 Jews escape from the Warsaw Ghetto by smuggling them out in ambulances, a truck, and via an underground passage. She then recorded their names on pieces of paper in hopes that their families could be reunited after World War II. The Soviets kept her activities secret; but in 1965, Poland's prime minister Władysław Gomułka publicized her efforts. As of 2009, she was the sole remaining survivor of the 21 who received the Jan Karski Award, bestowed by the Permanent Representatives to the Polish Government-in-Exile. In 1997, she was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize by Tadeusz Piotrowski, a history professor at the University of New Hampshire. She was nominated a second time in 2005 by President Lech Kaczyński, by Maria Jacek, and Jan Giesien. The nomination papers described her as "one of the righteous among the nations", referring to the "hidden" Jews whom Germans and other citizens of Nazi-occupied Poland helped to survive during World War II.

But still I love it and you should too, come see it for yourself, come taste the pain and ecstasy that are this mountain. It starts out with a walk up a winding uphill road flanked by foliage on one side, and if you look on the other side you see a sheer drop-off of 1000 feet into a raging, muddy torrent of water. This is the beginning of the adventure. After walking up this road for a while, you will see that the foliage starts to close in on both sides of the road, until the road itself is completely enclosed. You will be completely separated from the world, and you will feel as if you have entered a magical world, one where Death lurks around each corner of the road. And death is lurking there, waiting to snatch you up and carry you off, because this road is far too narrow and far too steep to walk, and in places there is no road at all and you have to jump from foothold to foothold with death on each side of you. But you will get to the top! And you will wish you had stayed on the road at the base because as you look down the steep, narrow path, you see people struggling to climb the path, where you felt the ease and magic of the path that surrounded you.

Humans have caused extinctions for hundreds, if not thousands, of years. The dodobird, for example, became extinct not so long ago. However, historically, human-caused extinctions have greatly accelerated. The species under the greatest threat of extinction today are the largest and slowest-to-reproduce among vertebrates. Human beings are inadvertently transforming Earth into an extinction machine, a condition which has a name: the Anthropocene epoch. The term is derived from anthropogenic, which means human-caused, and epoch, which is a time period on the geological calendar. This may be the first time since the end of the Mesozoic Era that a natural phenomenon is being largely influenced by a single species. The Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change describes human-caused extinctions as the result of unprecedented pressure on species by human activities.

Question: What is happening to the number of species on the Earth?
species under the greatest threat

title: Rhine
context: Since ~3000 yr BP (= years Before Present), human impact is seen in the delta. As a result of increasing land clearance (Bronze Age agriculture), in the upland areas (central Germany), the sediment load of the Rhine has strongly increased and delta growth has sped up. This caused increased flooding and sedimentation, ending peat formation in the delta. The shifting of river channels to new locations, on the floodplain (termed avulsion), was the main process distributing sediment across the subrecent delta. Over the past 6000 years, approximately 80 avulsions have occurred. Direct human impact in the delta started with peat mining, for salt and fuel, from Roman times onward. This was followed by embankment, of the major distributaries and damming of minor distributaries, which took place in the 11–13th century AD. Thereafter, canals were dug, bends were short cut and groynes were built, to prevent the river's channels from migrating or silting up.

Formed in 1946, Sierra Sky Park Airport is a residential airport community born of a unique agreement in transportation law to allow personal aircraft and automobiles to share certain roads. Sierra Sky Park was the first aviation community to be built[citation needed] and there are now numerous such communities across the United States and around the world. Developer William Smilie created the nation's first planned aviation community. Still in operation today, the public use airport provides a unique neighborhood that spawned interest and similar communities nationwide.

Passage:
Physical anthropology
Within the Western tradition, the understanding of the mechanisms of race formation has been central to the field of physical anthropology. The eighteenth-century naturalist Carl Linnaeus invented the modern concept of the human race, taxonomizing Homo sapiens into locally based subspecies ("Varieties", in his terminology) based on superficial traits. The Nineteenth century saw a dramatic expansion and refinement of this system, with anthropologists proposing such concepts as the "cognitive map" to explain the spatial organisation of native group relations in Oceania. At the same time, emerging theories of evolution were used to give a natural basis for the idea of human racial differentiation; on the other hand, others warned against a new form of scientific racism. 
Within the United States, the merging of anthropology with the study of law led to forensic anthropology and the development of methods for identifying human remains. Physical anthropology was firmly established within American academia during the early twentieth century. White Western anthropologists did fieldwork in the United States during the early twentieth century, studying "primitive" indigenous tribes. In the mid-twentieth century, the evolutionary study of races was made obsolete by developments in molecular biology and the introduction of DNA sequencing technologies. Across the field of anthropology, U.S. scholars moved away from focusing exclusively on the biological origins of human diversity, seeking to understand the development of human cultures, from the earliest times until the present, rather than racial origins of modern human diversity. At the same time, the focus on variation within modern human populations was not abandoned, and has instead been broadened into studies of the genetic human population history, whose major finding is that the divergence between human groups is highly superficial, with most variation found within rather than between groups.

Passage:
The American Civil War preserved the Union, and bolstered the national government's military power over that of the states. The population growth and capital investment necessary to begin building an industrial economy were concentrated through the government, funding national infrastructure projects like the transcontinental railways and establishing military-industrial complexes. Agriculture also received some support from the government, and for a while the National Banking Acts inflated the money supply, stimulating economic growth in that sector. The first transcontinental railroad created an efficient means to transport agricultural products, thus stimulating the Great Plains, growing and prospering for the first time with rapid agricultural and cattle booms. By 1860, American industrial output probably equaled that of Britain, making it the second only to the United States, despite the British Empire's vast colony markets, a small fraction of the country's total size and a decade of Civil War reducing industry.

Question:
What did the United States government do to support and fuel the American economy after the Civil War?
The United States government, after the Civil War, took several measures to support and fuel the American economy. It funded various national infrastructure projects like the transcontinental railways, which greatly improved the efficient transportation of agricultural products, promoting growth in the Great Plains and other regions. The government also established military-industrial complexes and invested in agriculture, implementing National Banking Acts that inflated the money supply, stimulating economic growth in this sector as well. By 1860, American industrial output had almost equaled that of Britain, making it the second only to the United States. However, it's worth noting that this achievement is despite the Civil War, which had reduced the country's industrial base.

title: Private school
context: In India, private schools are called independent schools, but since some private schools receive financial aid from the government, it can be an aided or an unaided school. So, in a strict sense, a private school is an unaided independent school. For the purpose of this definition, only receipt of financial aid is considered, not land purchased from the government at a subsidized rate. It is within the power of both the union government and the state governments to govern schools since Education appears in the Concurrent list of legislative subjects in the constitution. The practice has been for the union government to provide the broad policy directions while the states create their own rules and regulations for the administration of the sector. Among other things, this has also resulted in 30 different Examination Boards or academic authorities that conduct examinations for school leaving certificates. Prominent Examination Boards that are present in multiple states are the CBSE and the CISCE, NENBSE

title: Doctor Who
context: All the incidental music for the 2005 revived series has been composed by Murray Gold and Ben Foster and has been performed by the BBC National Orchestra of Wales from the 2005 Christmas episode "The Christmas Invasion" onwards. A concert featuring the orchestra performing music from the first two series took place on 19 November 2006 to raise money for Children in Need. David Tennant hosted the event, introducing the different sections of the concert. Murray Gold and Russell T Davies answered questions during the interval and Daleks and Cybermen appeared whilst music from their stories was played. The concert aired on BBCi on Christmas Day 2006. A Doctor Who Prom was celebrated on 27 July 2008 in the Royal Albert Hall as part of the annual BBC Proms. The BBC Philharmonic and the London Philharmonic Choir performed Murray Gold's compositions for the series, conducted by Ben Foster, as well as a selection of classics based on the theme of space and time. The event was presented by Freema Agyeman and guest-presented by various other stars of the show with numerous monsters participating in the proceedings. It also featured the specially filmed mini-episode "Music of the Spheres", written by Russell T Davies and starring David Tennant.

title: Construction
context: Building construction is the process of adding structure to real property or construction of buildings. The majority of building construction jobs are small renovations, such as addition of a room, or renovation of a bathroom. Often, the owner of the property acts as laborer, paymaster, and design team for the entire project. Although building construction projects typically include various common elements, such as design, financial, estimating and legal considerations, many projects of varying sizes reach undesirable end results, such as structural collapse, cost overruns, and/or litigation. For this reason, those with experience in the field make detailed plans and maintain careful oversight during the project to ensure a positive outcome.
